guideline: Display any variables that have a negative impact on your project

criteria.title: External variables
criteria.description: Any negative external variables affecting a product or service are displayed in a publicly available resource, identifying where your product's sustainable impact can be diminished (systemic design).

guideline: Understand visitor requirements or constraints, resolving barriers to access

criteria.title: Identify and define
criteria.description: Primary and secondary target visitors are identified, and their needs are defined through quantitative or qualitative research, testing, or analytics, ensuring your visitors and affected communities remain a close part of the research and testing process.

criteria.title: Visitor constraints
criteria.description: Potential visitor constraints like the device age, operating system version, browser, and connection speeds are accounted for when designing user experiences.

criteria.title: Barriers and access
criteria.description: The team has researched and identified whether a technical, material, or human constraint might require an adapted version of the product or service that reduces barriers or improves access to content.

criteria.title: Barrier removal
criteria.description: Barriers to access (pain points or dark / deceptive design patterns) have been identified in the user-research with visitors for removal.

criteria.title: Seat at the table
criteria.description: All stakeholders including your visitors have been assigned an equitable role in the decision-making process when undertaking research, identifying needs, or conducting iterative design work.

guideline: Understand the impact of non-visitors

criteria.title: Non-human impact
criteria.description: A plan of action has been established for non-users and other stakeholders who might be passively impacted by a digital product or service, such as neighbors accepting parcels, traffic jams due to deliveries, etc. Research their needs and understand how they might be affected.

guideline: Consider sustainability throughout the ideation process

criteria.title: Sustainable brand development
criteria.description: Branding materials and assets approved during the ideation process must be created and optimized in line with sustainability best practices before internal or external deployment. This also applies to brand refreshes, rebranding, and later enhancements. Branding guidelines detailing the sustainability impact and best-practice deployment of materials and assets should be made publicly available.

criteria.title: Wireframes and prototypes
criteria.description: Wireframes, and rapid prototyping are utilized to quickly build consensus, reduce risk, and lower the number of resources needed to build features.

criteria.title: Participation and testing
criteria.description: Users are involved within the iteration and design process using participatory design, and when conducting user-testing reach out to your community to help improve your product by allowing them to apply their knowledge and experience to your product or service.

guideline: Brainstorm ways to resolve any stakeholder issues

criteria.title: Human-centered brainstorming
criteria.description: All stakeholders have been considered using a human-centered approach during the brainstorming process.

criteria.title: Ecological brainstorming
criteria.description: The planetary needs and ecological boundaries of a project have been taken into account during the brainstorming process. This can include creating non-users, non-human (animal, planet) personas, or climate-specific user stories and sprints.

guideline: Minimize non-essential content, interactivity, or journeys

criteria.title: Efficient paths
criteria.description: The path taken to access the service (the initial contact with the website or service) should be as efficient and as simple as possible (time required to complete an action displayed, reducing too much choice, ensuring visitors know what's required at the start of a complex set of steps, etc).

criteria.title: Patterns for efficiency
criteria.description: The users journey (when browsing an accessed website or service) should be as smooth as possible. User-research is key, as is building on established design patterns that people already understand.

criteria.title: Distraction-free design
criteria.description: Visitors can complete tasks without distractions or non-essential features getting in the way.

criteria.title: Eliminate the non-essential
criteria.description: Visitors see only information that is relevant to their experience, without non-essential information being displayed on the screen.

criteria.title: User-initiated actionable content
criteria.description: Ensure that actionable information such as pop-up or modal windows can only be initiated by the visitor.

guideline: Use decorative design with care

criteria.title: Decorative design
criteria.description: Decorative design is used only when it improves the user experience, and unnecessary assets or ones that fail to benefit the visitor or sustainability are removed (or rendered optional and disabled by default).

guideline: Ensure that navigation and way-finding are well-structured

criteria.title: Navigation and search
criteria.description: Provide an accessible, easy-to-use navigation menu with search features that help visitors easily find what they need.

criteria.title: Navigable sitemaps
criteria.description: Implement an efficient (human-readable) sitemap that is organized and is regularly updated. This helps search engines better index website content, which helps visitors more quickly find what they are looking for.

criteria.title: New content
criteria.description: Implement a way for visitors to find out about new content and services.

guideline: Be attentive rather than distracting

criteria.title: Respecting attention
criteria.description: The visitor can easily control how (and when) they receive information to both improve attention and respect with the visitor.

criteria.title: Avoid distraction
criteria.description: Features that don't distract people or unnecessarily lengthen the time they spend using the product or service have a higher priority than others.

criteria.title: Avoid attention-keeping
criteria.description: Avoid using infinite scroll or related attention-keeping tactics.

guideline: Use established design patterns and appropriate components

criteria.title: Design patterns
criteria.description: Provide only essential components visible at the time they are needed. Where appropriate, interfaces should deploy visual styles (patterns) that are easily recognized and used.

guideline: Avoid being manipulative or deceptive

criteria.title: Dark and deceptive design patterns
criteria.description: Avoid what are commonly known as dark patterns, deceptive design, or unethical coding techniques, which manipulate visitors into taking actions not necessarily in their best interest (anti-right click, no-copy, requiring an account to purchase, etc).

criteria.title: Using advertisements
criteria.description: Advertisements and sponsorships are both ethical and clearly identified with the product or service, only presenting them when they provide real economic and ethical value and don't diminish a visitor's experience.

criteria.title: Page tracking
criteria.description: Remove unused and unconsented page tracking.

criteria.title: Search Engine Optimization
criteria.description: Optimization for search engines, social networks, and third-party services are organically led with good coding practices with user experience the focus, not manipulating the services to gain greater priority through obfuscating content, pages, websites, or applications with redundancy or non-useful and optimized (to the visitor) material.

guideline: Enable others to understand and reuse your deliverables

criteria.title: Deliverables reusability
criteria.description: The deliverables output, including documentation, are used upstream of the project and produced in ways that will allow it to be reused in subsequent projects.

criteria.title: Deliverables documentation
criteria.description: Design functionality and technical specifications are documented so that deliverables are comprehensible by the project team and transferable to the development team.

criteria.title: Deliverables readability
criteria.description: Developers have access to code comments and other View Source affordances which can reduce the burden to access, understand, maintain, and utilize production-ready code as this will reduce redundancy and foster an open source culture.

guideline: Use a design system to prioritize interface consistency

criteria.title: Design system
criteria.description: A design system is employed based on web standards and recognizable patterns to mutualize interface components and provide a consistent experience for visitors.

guideline: Write with purpose, in an accessible, easy-to-understand format

criteria.title: Write clearly
criteria.description: Content is written clearly, using plain, inclusive language delivered at an easy-to-understand reading level considering accessibility and internationalization inclusions as required (for example, dyslexia).

criteria.title: Content formatting
criteria.description: Content is formatted to support how people read online, including a clear document structure, visual hierarchy, headings, bulleted lists, line spacing, and so on.

criteria.title: Search Engine Optimization (SEO)
criteria.description: SEO has been prioritized from the early design stages and throughout a product or service's lifecycle to improve content findability.

guideline: All images must be optimized for sustainability

criteria.title: Need for images
criteria.description: The need for images has been determined considering the quantity, format, and size necessary for implementation.

criteria.title: Optimize images
criteria.description: Resize, optimize, and compress each image (outside the browser), offering different sizes (for each image) for different screen resolutions.

criteria.title: Lazy loading
criteria.description: Provide Lazy Loading to ensure image assets only load when they are required.

criteria.title: Sizing and deactivation
criteria.description: Let the visitor select the display size, and provide the option to deactivate images.

criteria.title: Management and usage
criteria.description: Set up a media management and use policy to reduce the overall impact of images, with criteria for media compression and file formats.

guideline: All audio or video must be optimized for sustainability

criteria.title: Need for media
criteria.description: The need for video or sound (when it adds visitor value, for example, to enhance accessibility) has been determined, and non-informative media (background media), including autoplaying functionality, has been banned or removed.

criteria.title: Optimize media
criteria.description: Compress the media according to the visitor's requirements, select the appropriate format, ensure it works across browsers, and avoid embedded player plugins.

criteria.title: Lazy loading
criteria.description: Any media requiring a lot of data to be downloaded on the client side (including the media itself) has been loaded behind a facade (a non-functional, static, representational element).

criteria.title: Labels and choice
criteria.description: Let the visitor control media deactivation, giving a choice of resolutions; all while providing alternative resolutions and formats. Also increase visitor awareness by informing them of the length, format, and weight of the media.

criteria.title: Management and usage
criteria.description: Set up a media management and use policy to reduce the overall impact of audio and video, with criteria for media compression and file formats.

guideline: Animation must be proportionate and easy to control

criteria.title: Need for animation
criteria.description: Use animation only when it adds value to a visitor's experience, and not for decorative elements.

criteria.title: Avoid overburdening
criteria.description: Progressively display an appropriate number of animations to avoid overburden the visitor or diminish expected device behavior. This includes setting a maximum number of replays (iterations).

criteria.title: Control animation
criteria.description: Allow visitors to start, stop, pause, or otherwise control animated content.

guideline: Web typography must be highly optimized and appropriate

criteria.title: Default typefaces
criteria.description: Use standard system-level (web-safe / pre-installed) fonts as much as possible.

criteria.title: Font optimization
criteria.description: The number of fonts, and the variants within typefaces (such as weight and characters) are limited within a project, using the most performant file format available.

guideline: Suitable alternatives to any provided format must be offered

criteria.title: Open formats
criteria.description: All proprietary file formats (such as PDF) are offered in HTML for accessibility and to ensure future availability.

criteria.title: Font subsetting
criteria.description: All custom typefaces (using font-display) are subsetted and offered as part of a font stack with a system font as a backup.

criteria.title: Alternative text
criteria.description: All images provide meaningful alternative text for screen reader users (or when images fail to load) accessibility.

criteria.title: Audio alternatives
criteria.description: Audio provides text transcripts of conversations as an alternative to playing the media.

criteria.title: Video alternatives
criteria.description: Video provides text transcripts (at minimum), subtitles (using WebVTT), and for accessibility best practice, offer closed captions and sign language options.

guideline: Provide accessible, usable, minimal web forms

criteria.title: Form simplicity
criteria.description: Remove unnecessary forms and reduce form content to the bare minimum necessary to meet the visitor's needs and the organization's business goals. Clearly communicate why a form is necessary, what its value proposition is, how many steps it will take to complete, and what an organization will do with collected data (informed consent).

criteria.title: Form functionality
criteria.description: Avoid auto-completion / auto-suggest if it would prove unhelpful (to conserve bandwidth) whilst allowing autofill for ease of repeat entry (including the use of helpful tooling such as password managers).

guideline: Consider the impact of visitors using non-visual browsers

criteria.title: Alternative interactions
criteria.description: Support speech browsing and other non-graphical ways to interact with content that provide alternatives to a visual interface.

guideline: Provide useful notifications to improve the visitor's journey

criteria.title: Notification justification
criteria.description: Remove non-essential notifications while justifying and reducing the practice of e-mailing or text messaging to what is strictly necessary. Useful notifications (such as alerts for new content) should be used with care and restraint.

criteria.title: Notification control
criteria.description: Let the visitor control notifications (for example through the browser, SMS, or by email) and adjust messaging preferences, and the option to unsubscribe, logout, and close an account should be available and visible.

criteria.title: Prompts and responses
criteria.description: Clearly explain the result of a potential input through helpful prompts and messages that explain errors, next steps, and so on. This will help manage their expectations.

guideline: Reduce the impact of downloadable or physical documents

criteria.title: Printing documents
criteria.description: If the production of paper documents is essential, it should be designed to limit its impact to the lowest possible. Create a CSS Print stylesheet and test it with different types of content. Ensure PDF printing is encouraged over paper-based storage.

criteria.title: Optimize documents
criteria.description: Provide all downloadable documents in a state of being optimized, compressed, and in a variety of accessible file formats.

criteria.title: Optimize delivery
criteria.description: If a document is likely to be re-used, generate the document once on the server-side (preferably on a cookie-free domain) rather than forcing the effort to be duplicated.

criteria.title: Labels and choice
criteria.description: Clearly display the document name, a summary, the file size, and the format, allowing the visitor a choice if possible of both the format, and the language (if not the same as the web page). Furthermore, be sure to avoid embedding the document within Web pages (provide a direct link to download or view within the browser instead).

guideline: Policies and processes must exist to get stakeholders invested

criteria.title: New features and perspectives
criteria.description: The organization has outlined processes it uses to prototype and test new features, product ideas, and user-interface components when applicable with real users who represent various stakeholder perspectives, including people with slow connection, with disabilities, with difficulties using digital services, and so on.

criteria.title: Resourcing and viability
criteria.description: The organization has appropriately resourced these processes to support its long-term product viability.

criteria.title: Training and onboarding
criteria.description: The organization has training materials to onboard new product team members to these practices.

criteria.title: Testing and validation
criteria.description: The organization regularly conducts extensive testing and user interviews to validate whether the released features are meeting both business goals and visitor needs.

guideline: Audit and test for bugs or issues that require resolving

criteria.title: Regular issue testing
criteria.description: The codebase has been checked for bugs, performance issues have been identified, and accessibility or security problems have been accounted for at either monthly or quarterly timeframes (depending on your scheduling allowance).

criteria.title: Non-regression tests
criteria.description: Non-regression tests are implemented for all important functionality.

criteria.title: Regression tests
criteria.description: Regression testing has been incorporated into each release cycle to ensure that new features don't introduce bugs or otherwise conflict with existing software functionality.

guideline: Measure and test for performance

criteria.title: Performance testing
criteria.description: The performance of a website or application, to identify and resolve bottlenecks or issues in the underlying code or infrastructure which could ultimately impact the sustainability of a website or application, are regularly measured with each release-cycle (using tooling or through research and auditing).

criteria.title: Measurement and compliance
criteria.description: Only data required to provide a streamlined and effective user-journey, put policies in place to ensure strict adherence, and comply with relevant accessibility policies and privacy laws, such as the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) are collected.

guideline: Ensure features provide maximum value for their impact

criteria.title: Usage changes
criteria.description: Visitor feedback, adoption, and churn rates are monitored of product or service features and their insights incorporated into future releases.

guideline: Verify that real-world users can successfully use your work

criteria.title: Usability testing
criteria.description: Usability testing has been incorporated into product cycles and the impact of these tests is routinely measured for future releases.

guideline: Check for compatibility or platform-specific issues

criteria.title: Compatibility policy
criteria.description: A compatibility policy with obsolete devices and software versions, listing the supported devices brands, operating systems, and browsers (including versions) has been established.

criteria.title: Maintaining compatibility
criteria.description: Planned obsolescence in software updates is routinely avoided, striving to maintain compatibility for as long as possible and clearly communicating whether an update is evolutionary (large updates that can significantly reduce performance) or corrective (smaller updates that fix bugs or improve security).

criteria.title: Frequent testing
criteria.description: The product or service regularly tests with weak, unstable, restricted, and slow connections, old browsers, and devices older than five years to ensure compatibility, reduce digital inequalities, and minimize barriers for users.

criteria.title: Mobile friendly
criteria.description: Device-adaptable methods (such as responsive design) are utilized and interfaces are prototyped to ensure progressive enhancement, content prioritization, and improved accessibility.

criteria.title: Progressive Web Applications (PWAs)
criteria.description: A PWA has been either chosen or rejected based on whether it be more sustainable and compatible over a native mobile application.

guideline: Set goals based on potential impact considerations

criteria.title: Performance goals
criteria.description: Explicit goals that impact the environment and performance of the service, for example, HTTP requests, or the amount of DOM elements that need to be rendered are both set and met.

criteria.title: Accountancy types
criteria.description: Because the payload being delivered may not always be equal in terms of energy intensity, operators of websites and applications must ensure that consideration is given for the energy intensity (or unit being evaluated) of each component. For example, non-rendering text is less computational than CSS, which in turn is less process-heavy than JavaScript, which is less resource-heavy than WebGL.

guideline: Remove unnecessary or redundant information

criteria.title: Minify code
criteria.description: Remove unnecessary whitespace, comments, and other non-essential characters from code and data files to reduce file sizes and improve loading times. This applies to HTML, CSS, JavaScript, JSON, SVG, and other relevant file types.

guideline: Modularize bandwidth-heavy components within projects

criteria.title: Code splitting
criteria.description: Break down bandwidth-heavy components, front-end and back-end into smaller, modular segments that can be loaded only when required.

guideline: Tree shaking should be used to remove unnecessary code

criteria.title: Remove redundancy
criteria.description: Identify and eliminate unused and dead code within CSS and JavaScript.

guideline: Redundancy and duplication in code should be avoided

criteria.title: Remove or simplify
criteria.description: Remove or simplify (through rewriting for performance) your code to focus on essential features and have a cleaner, less redundant product (and codebase).

criteria.title: Iteration over recreation
criteria.description: Improve (iterate) an existing creation rather than constantly redeveloping and redesigning products from scratch (duplication of coding effort) if possible to reduce visitor learning burden and developer impact.

criteria.title: Organize code arrangement
criteria.description: Within CSS and JavaScript, use methodologies (like BEM) and systems like DRY and WET to optimize the arrangement and output of your source code.

guideline: Third-party services should be assessed as first parties

criteria.title: Assess third-parties
criteria.description: Third-party services (including plugins, widgets, feeds, maps, carousels, etc) have been assessed as early in the ideation or creation process as possible and as few of them are used as possible to reduce the product or service's overall ecological impact, including Scope 3 emissions.

criteria.title: Third-party implementation
criteria.description: Third-party content (including plugins, widgets, feeds, maps, carousels, chat widgets, etc) that loads or requests resources or functionality from a location outside of the primary location, should be placed behind a click-to-load delay screen (using the "import on interaction" pattern), while alternatives are offered, for instance a link to a contact form as an alternative for a chat widget.

criteria.title: Libraries and frameworks
criteria.description: Large CSS libraries and JavaScript frameworks are only be used if a more performant alternative that achieves the same goal cannot be used instead.

criteria.title: Self-hosting
criteria.description: Self-hosted content has been prioritized over embedded content from third-party services.

criteria.title: Avoiding dependency
criteria.description: Your own clickable icons and widgets have been created, rather than relying on third-party services to host or allow embedding within your product or service.

criteria.title: Third-party preferences
criteria.description: Third-party products, services, libraries, and frameworks are often a source of sustainability issues that cannot be controlled or managed by the first-party provider of a service. While many do provide benefits to a website, the need to justify their inclusion must be made not only by those creating the product or service but also be able to be controlled by the consumer. As showcased with cookies, websites or applications can provide a similar mechanism of disabling or refusing non-first-party features (with explanations of their purpose) - unless such features can be proven as critical for functionality.

guideline: Code must follow good semantic practices

criteria.title: Semantic code
criteria.description: Content must be accurately marked up according to the relevant standard(s).

criteria.title: Optional features
criteria.description: Remove optional HTML tags, attribute quotes, and default attributes only when they do not negatively impact functionality, accessibility, or readability. Retain them when they enhance accessibility, maintain clarity (without compromising on performance), or ensure consistent browser rendering.

criteria.title: Avoid non-standard code
criteria.description: Avoid using non-standard elements or attributes.

criteria.title: Custom code
criteria.description: Prefer using standard HTML elements and attributes. Only use custom elements or Web Components if you cannot utilize native HTML elements or if you need tightly regulated control over the implementation of design system components..

guideline: Render blocking should be resolved

criteria.title: Asynchronous code
criteria.description: All external assets have been deferred or set to async (unless required) to avoid Flash Of Unstyled Content (FOUC).

criteria.title: Priority loading
criteria.description: If external resources are required on load, their priorities (delivery route) are set correctly.

guideline: Information to help understand the usefulness of a page should exist

criteria.title: Metadata and microdata
criteria.description: Metadata and microdata for search engines and social media have been optimized.

criteria.title: Search engines
criteria.description: Search engines are not obstructed, while ill-intentioned robots and scripts are blocked.

criteria.title: Accessibility aids
criteria.description: Accessibility and usability aids are provided to find content, such as skip links and signposts.

guideline: Forms must validate for errors, accounting for tooling requirements

criteria.title: Error validation
criteria.description: Errors are identified through live validation as well as upon submission.

criteria.title: Label elements
criteria.description: Required elements are clearly identified and labeled (for the benefit of voice tools such as screen readers and virtual assistants), and optional elements (if unnecessary) removed.

criteria.title: Allow paste
criteria.description: Always allow the pasting of content (including passwords) from external sources.

guideline: Metadata is structured for machine readability

criteria.title: Required elements
criteria.description: Include the required title element, plus any optional HTML head elements (such as link).

criteria.title: Meta tags
criteria.description: Include necessary meta tag references that search engines and social networks recognize, using a recognized name scheme such as Dublin Core Metadata Initiative (DCMI), Friend Of A Friend (FOAF), or RDFa.

criteria.title: Structured data
criteria.description: Embed Microdata, Structured Data (Schema), or Microformats within your pages.

guideline: Sustainable CSS user preference media queries are used

criteria.title: Media and preference queries
criteria.description: Apply the monochrome, prefers-contrast, prefers-color-scheme, prefers-reduced-data, prefers-reduced-transparency, and prefers-reduced-motion CSS preference queries if they will benefit your website or application. Use the print & scripting CSS media queries if they will improve the sustainability of your website.

guideline: Layouts work across devices and requirements

criteria.title: Mobile-first
criteria.description: Allow a website or app to work and adapt seamlessly across a variety of devices and screen sizes, including mobile, desktop, smart TVs, and other emerging platforms. Ensures that content and functionality are accessible and optimized on both smaller mobile screens and larger displays without limiting accessibility, usability or design on any specific device type. It is essential to implement robust fallback strategies to ensure that the website or application will not fail if it encounters unsupported technologies.

criteria.title: Progressive enhancement
criteria.description: Regardless of the approach or combination of approaches used, such as Adaptive Design, Mobile-First Design, or Dynamic Serving, it's essential to ensure overall sustainability through progressive enhancement.

criteria.title: Carbon aware design
criteria.description: To maximize the use of renewable energy, adapt your website or service to electricity availability using carbon-aware design techniques. This should include using situational design to reduce the codebase disable non-essential functionality during high-intensity periods or adapting the user-interface to perform better in situations where scaling hardware resources can be avoided to reduce emissions. It can also include designing algorithms that can auto-disable features based on set thresholds.

criteria.title: Alternative browsing
criteria.description: Support other indirect methods of interaction such as voice (speech), code (QR, etc), reader view (browser, application, or RSS), or connected technology (watch, appliance, transport, etc).

guideline: Use beneficial JavaScript and its APIs

criteria.title: Beneficial JavaScript
criteria.description: Improve sustainability through accessible and performant code implementations.

criteria.title: Sustainable APIs
criteria.description: Apply potential energy-reducing APIs (such as Battery Status, Compression Streams, Page Visibility, and Vibration) if they can improve the eco-efficiency of your website or application.

criteria.title: API requests
criteria.description: When using an API, make sure you only call it when necessary. On the other side, make sure no unrequired data is sent by the API.

guideline: Ensure that your scripts are secure

criteria.title: Script security
criteria.description: Check the code for vulnerabilities, exploits, header issues, and code injection.

guideline: Dependencies are appropriately used and maintained

criteria.title: Dependency management
criteria.description: Prevent developers from downloading and installing JavaScript libraries to run locally (client-side) when they are not needed by checking for unused dependencies and uninstalling those that aren't needed and removing them from your package.json file.

criteria.title: Dependency necessity
criteria.description: Only use libraries where necessary as this will reduce the amount of JavaScript that has to be downloaded and parsed by the browser. Consider whether you can use a native JavaScript API instead. Check the package size, and whether individual modules can be installed and imported rather than the whole library.

criteria.title: Dependency updates
criteria.description: Regularly check dependencies and keep them up-to-date.

guideline: Include expected and beneficial files

criteria.title: Expected file formats
criteria.description: Include the favicon.ico, robots.txt, opensearch.xml, site.webmanifest, and sitemap.xml documents. Additionally, ensure that any such files defined in future web standards or specifications are included.

criteria.title: Beneficial file formats
criteria.description: Include beneficial files such as ads.txt, carbon.txt, humans.txt, security.txt. Additionally, ensure that any such files defined in future web standards or specifications are included.

guideline: Avoid using deprecated, proprietary, or outdated code

criteria.title: Preferred code
criteria.description: Avoid the use of deprecated, proprietary, or outdated formats and web standards. Always adopt up-to-date, widely recognized standards that offer equivalent or improved functionality. Such code may be used to meet a documented customer need only if there is a justifiable benefit that cannot otherwise be met (such as compatibility, accessibility, or emissions reduction). Also, don't serve polyfills to modern browsers.

guideline: Use the most efficient solution to implement your service

criteria.title: Identify requirements
criteria.description: Identify the requirements and from this, choose the implementation of the product or service. A simpler technological implementation may use more human resources but could have a smaller footprint. A prebuilt solution may use more system resources (and thereby produce more emissions upon render) but have a faster build-time (emitting less carbon during development).

criteria.title: Optimized methodology
criteria.description: As a general rule, coding from scratch is the best-performing methodology (though if an existing solution is actively maintained, it may be better optimized than what you could produce). Therefore, use native components and file systems to a WYSIWYG editor or heavy framework, and be considerate of the impact of third-party solutions.

criteria.title: Static VS dynamic
criteria.description: If choosing a code generation tool, use a Static Site Generator in preference to a bulky content management system. Because SSGs often start using a minimalist content entry format (like markdown) and all of the compilation is done before the website is uploaded, the emissions benefit comes from the server not having to place as much effort into serving pages (as they are static) for each visitor. In the case of a CMS, the dynamic nature of a site will involve additional computation (server-side processing) and bulkier libraries.

criteria.title: Expandability considerations
criteria.description: Plugins, extensions, and themes have been carefully reviewed and selected to maximize interoperability, accessibility, and performance. They are regularly audited over time to ensure continued compatibility.

criteria.title: Interface impact
criteria.description: All the components of the user-interface are the subject of special attention in terms of its sustainability impact while respecting accessibility and the performance of such components.

guideline: Use the latest stable language version

criteria.title: Versioning
criteria.description: Use the latest build of your chosen syntax language and its coupled framework.

criteria.title: Language choice
criteria.description: Use the most appropriate programming language for a task. Many tools and programming languages are optimized for performing particular tasks, and utilizing those most appropriate to the problem, especially if there is a reasonable visitor base involved justifies the time and effort, as long as it doesn't impact PPP factors such as the well-being of those involved or become too cost prohibitive.

guideline: Take advantage of native features and functionality

criteria.title: Native over custom
criteria.description: Use native functions, APIs, and features over writing your own.

guideline: Run fewer, simpler queries as possible

criteria.title: Database queries
criteria.description: If you need information that is stored in a database, and you require it (or it's likely to be requested) more than once in your code, access the database only once, and store the data locally for subsequent processing. Also, avoid reliance on framework helpers that might defer filtering to later on in the process.

guideline: Choose a sustainable hosting provider

criteria.title: Monitor metrics
criteria.description: To assess the environmental impacts of hosting and detect overconsumption, some indicators are monitored: energy / water usage, CPU / Memory usage, allocation of servers and CPU cores, etc. These indicators are be used to calculate metrics directly related to environmental impacts, such as Power Usage Effectiveness (PUE), Water Usage Effectiveness (WUE), and Carbon Usage Effectiveness (CUE). They are displayed to visitors for transparency and monitoring reasons. If possible (to reduce redundancy) the ability to scale packages based on usage requirements is made available (manually or automatically) to reduce wasted resources.

criteria.title: Equipment longevity
criteria.description: Equipment is managed responsibly by keeping it as long as possible, using it as efficiently as possible, making sure it is certified, and purchasing long-lifespan products.

criteria.title: Recycling waste
criteria.description: Waste (including equipment) is recovered, recycled, and upcycled.

criteria.title: Renewable electricity
criteria.description: Electricity comes entirely from sources with the lowest possible carbon intensity (ideally generated by wind or solar rather than from non-renewable sources). For example, Renewable Energy Credits (RECs) can help verify the source, or, ideally, prove that electricity comes directly from renewable sources.

criteria.title: Remaining emissions
criteria.description: Remaining emissions are compensated, keeping in mind that the priority should be to avoid then reduce them and only compensate for them if they cannot be avoided. Carbon credits may not be sustainable, therefore the effectiveness of an offset solution must be verified, shown to be both environmentally viable and sustainable, and part of a longer-term strategy to eliminate emissions entirely from a chain, benefitting the wider ecosystem.

guideline: Optimize caching with offline access supported

criteria.title: Utilize caching
criteria.description: If using a CMS or (SaaS), install an applicable plugin to enable on-the-fly server-side caching. Otherwise, use the provided server configuration files to include and tweak the file-type cache expiration using expires or cache-control, utilizing tooling where appropriate such as Memcached, or Varnish. If using a language or framework that generates pages on request, cache responses for static pages so that they can be reused for future visitors. Also remember to cache frequently required static assets at the client-side where possible to reduce repeat server requests using bfcache, Local Storage, and other available browser technologies.

criteria.title: Offline access
criteria.description: Client-side JavaScript uses a combination of ServiceWorkers, WebWorkers, storage Application Programming Interfaces (APIs), or cookies (if necessary) to streamline the user-journey. For example, through the use of a PWA (Progressive Web Application) to ensure that an offline version is available and accessible at all times to reduce inequality and improve accessibility.

guideline: Compress files where it is beneficial

criteria.title: Server-side compression
criteria.description: If using a CMS, install an applicable plugin to enable on-the-fly server-side compression, such as Brotli or GZIP. Otherwise, use the provided server configuration files to include and tweak the performance-related features to the requirements.

criteria.title: Media compression
criteria.description: Compress your various images, fonts, audio, and video; by reducing the quality and offering different resolutions / dimensions (sizes) before uploading to a server or content management system.

guideline: Setup necessary error pages and redirection links

criteria.title: Error pages
criteria.description: Maintain sites by ensuring links are correct, and if errors occur, provide suitable way-finding within optimized pages for each error type to ensure resources can be identified to help visitors complete the task they started.

criteria.title: redirection
criteria.description: Redirect websites, subdomains, and pages only when necessary. Proactively seek broken or outdated links and fix them. A redirect or search will often help reduce the number of pages a visitor needs to load.

guideline: Unless required, avoid utilizing unnecessary environments

criteria.title: Unused environments
criteria.description: Ensure no unused environment is available, balancing the cost of deploying an environment with the cost of keeping it online while unused.

guideline: Allow automation but ensure it is tightly regulated

criteria.title: Automate tasks
criteria.description: Every recurring task, such as deployment, testing, or compilation, is run automatically, as recommended by continuous integration / continuous delivery best practices.

criteria.title: Necessitate tasks
criteria.description: To reduce wasted processing cycles, every automated task is only run when needed.

criteria.title: Automated scaling
criteria.description: Automated scaling infrastructure is used to automatically increase the capacity of the web server and buffering / throttling is implemented to respond to visitor demand.

criteria.title: Security tooling
criteria.description: Web browsing from bots has been steadily increasing in recent years. As such, it is a growing concern for security, performance, and sustainability. Use security tools that automatically block bad actors and minimize bad behavior. This results in substantially less load on the server, fewer logs, less data, less effect due to compromise, and more. The result of compromised websites is a large increase in HTTP, email, and other traffic as malicious code attempts to infiltrate other resources and exfiltrate data. Compromised websites are typically identified by anomalous patterned behavior.

guideline: Define the frequency of data refreshes

criteria.title: Refresh frequency
criteria.description: The frequency for refresh (of both the cache, locally stored data, and the page) is defined depending on visitor needs.

guideline: Backup critical data at routine intervals

criteria.title: Data backups
criteria.description: Backups of system and user data are both incremental and secure.

guideline: Consider the impact and requirements of processing information

criteria.title: Batch processing
criteria.description: By default, non-critical processes and communications are batched and launched only when carbon intensity is under a given threshold.

criteria.title: Protocol usage
criteria.description: The communication protocols used are relevant to the visitor's needs and data transferred. Avoid using insecure protocols (HTTP, FTP), and prioritize more efficient and privacy-aware data routes for visitors (HTTPS, SSH). Modern protocols such as HTTP/2 should be used to benefit from them (multiplexing) while keeping backward-compatibility in mind for older devices.

criteria.title: Event-driven architecture
criteria.description: When creating products or services that utilize state changes (without triggering a complete refresh), if the utilization of Event-Driven Architecture and Microservices will be more environmentally friendly (based on the PPP variables involved) than traditional APIs in handling the server-side workload of your solution, use it.

criteria.title: Client VS server
criteria.description: Redundant processing should be avoided wherever possible. When processing of data is required, whether such processing and / or delivery should occur from either the client or server-side must be determined based on efficiency, performance, and sustainability metrics (before implementation).

guideline: CDN use must be proportionate and sustainable

criteria.title: Content Delivery Networks (CDNs)
criteria.description: When building for a globally distributed audience, use a CDN to store and serve simple read-only, pre-generated resources in a fast and efficient manner. Although they definitely can increase performance, it is also another layer of infrastructure that needs to be considered for sustainability.

criteria.title: Sustainability commitment
criteria.description: Verify that the CDN provides a commitment to sustainability.

criteria.title: Local servers
criteria.description: A hosting provider was chosen with servers located close to the visitor, considering that if you only serve a local audience, the need for distributed content (CDNs) that duplicate your materials globally may not be worthwhile.

criteria.title: Inappropriate resources
criteria.description: Don't use the service to host dynamic / regularly changing resources or JavaScript (unless through a first-party host) as due to cache partitioning, cross-origin resource sharing (CORS), and other browser mechanics, any benefits are negated by weaker performance, the inability to cache or interact, and the potential introduction of security and privacy issues to be introduced. This doesn't affect JSON or other static assets.

criteria.title: Close to the source
criteria.description: All information passed between the layers of an application incurs a cost, both in terms of data transferred, and CPU cycles for (de)serialization. Wherever possible, data transformations must be performed close to the source to reduce these costs and avoid processing data that will later be discarded.

guideline: Infrastructure decisions must meet business requirements

criteria.title: Lowest requirements
criteria.description: Select infrastructure elements with the lowest requirements tier, meeting your service-level agreements. Avoid over-provisioning multi-datacenter, multi-zone, or distributed deployments if standalone instances meet the requirements. Also avoid provisioning infrastructure that will be under-utilized by provisioning for established average loads, ensuring reasonable resource utilization and autoscaling occurs as needed. Avoid provisioning for peak loads.

guideline: Store data according to the needs of your users

criteria.title: Reduce redundancy
criteria.description: Remove unnecessary and redundant data from your servers, whether it is single-use (dark data) or abandoned.

criteria.title: Expiration dates
criteria.description: Create data with an expiration date. Excess data is a form of technical debt, and routinely cleaning up old data needs to be normalized.

criteria.title: Classify and tag
criteria.description: Use a data classification / tagging policy to make it easier to find, handle, and remove.

criteria.title: Justify storage
criteria.description: Store data only when it is difficult to recreate.

criteria.title: Optimize logging
criteria.description: Optimize log collection, storage (off-site), and rotation; scheduling during low-activity hours and using carbon-neutral backup providers.

criteria.title: Asset downloads
criteria.description: Ensure long-term assets, especially those of a large size, are made available for download.

guideline: Have an ethical and sustainable product strategy

criteria.title: Statement availability
criteria.description: The organization has published a publicly available Code of Ethics, Product Guidelines, Sustainability, or PPP Statement that includes language specific to digital products, services, policies, and programs.

criteria.title: Achievements and compliance
criteria.description: Achievements, features, compliance, and anything beyond the scope of these guidelines are published within a sustainability section of your product or service.

criteria.title: Governance over time
criteria.description: Evidence is provided by the organization showing how it effectively governs implemented digital sustainability, climate policies, and related PPP practices over time.

criteria.title: Onboarding new members
criteria.description: Training decks and workshops are provided by the organization for onboarding new team members on how it implements more sustainable product strategies.

criteria.title: Documentation
criteria.description: Your methodology has been documented through impact storytelling, documentation, and helping individuals make more informed decisions in order to raise awareness with your visitors.

criteria.title: Renewable showcasing
criteria.description: The organization can show how it powers digital products and services with renewable energy.

guideline: Assign a sustainability representative

criteria.title: Ecological referee
criteria.description: An ecological referee (with specific digital expertise) for the product or service within your organization has been assigned and empowered with the tools they require (resources, budget, time, etc.) to achieve their stated goals.

guideline: Inform, raise awareness, and train for sustainability

criteria.title: Inform and aware
criteria.description: All project stakeholders, including product teams, colleagues, and organizational decision-makers (managers and clients) are informed about and trained in both general and digital climate literacy, including your business's use of sustainable technology.

criteria.title: Trained and prepared
criteria.description: Active and routine training is delivered where possible to develop, establish, and refresh skills in sustainability. This can be undertaken through in-house training, courses, workshops, events, webinars, meetups, or other ongoing or on-demand methods to empower your team to deliver on sustainability objectives.

criteria.title: Active participation
criteria.description: Stakeholders have been actively encouraged to reduce their environmental impact, share climate and sustainable initiatives and ideas, and resources on sustainable design, best practices, and concepts are provided to assist with this task.

guideline: Communicate the ecological impact of user choices

criteria.title: Impact communication
criteria.description: The ecological implications of visitor choices have been clearly communicated and visitors can configure settings based on those choices.

guideline: Estimate a product or service's environmental impact

criteria.title: Life-cycle analysis
criteria.description: A full life-cycle Analysis based on the functional unit defined in Guideline 5.15 has been conducted.

criteria.title: Competitor impact
criteria.description: The environmental impact of your or a competitor's current service to inform decision-making (as a potential target goal) has been calculated.

criteria.title: Tooling impact
criteria.description: When identifying the environmental impact of your product or service, you must include the impact (or estimates of) of any tooling used to create the product or service along with any third-party solutions utilized in the pipeline. While not created by you, the emissions they generate from production to maintenance are considered integral to your overall solution.

guideline: Define clear organizational sustainability goals and metrics

criteria.title: Sustainability goals
criteria.description: The organization has defined and published a clear set of sustainability goals. It publicly communicates how it will meet these goals, including which performance metrics are important to help the organization and its various stakeholders thrive.

guideline: Verify your efforts using established third-party business certifications

criteria.title: Certification achievement
criteria.description: The organization has achieved one or more business sustainability certifications and incorporated operational policies and practices to support them.

criteria.title: Certification maintenance
criteria.description: The organization maintains its certification through evolving policies and practices over time.

guideline: Implement sustainability onboarding guidelines

criteria.title: Training materials
criteria.description: The organization has dedicated training manuals, workshops, and materials that outline the PPP policies and practices it follows and how to implement them. While managing and maintaining these materials over time, adapting them as new policies and practices arise.

criteria.title: Progress incentivisation
criteria.description: The organization incentivizes leadership, teams, and stakeholders to make progress toward the goals outlined in their training, including time for sustainability activities, recognition for completion, and so on.

criteria.title: Negative variables
criteria.description: The organization anticipates and maps potential negative external variables on the service, and acts to minimize their overall impact.

guideline: Support mandatory disclosures and reporting

criteria.title: Policies and practices
criteria.description: The organization has created and published policies and practices for disclosing the social and environmental impacts of its products, services, policies, and programs in line with existing reporting standards such as GRI Performance, SASB, etc.

criteria.title: Impact report
criteria.description: The organization produces a publicly available impact report outlining its progress against previous reports on social and environmental goals at least once per year.

criteria.title: Standards and policies
criteria.description: The organization publicly and transparently follows existing or emerging environmental standards and legislative policy that promotes mandatory disclosures and reporting for emissions. This is done alongside other social and environmental criteria in its impact reporting, maintaining these practices over time for future reports.

criteria.title: Impact reduction
criteria.description: The organization clearly identifies how it reduces its environmental impact, avoiding double accounting, greenwashing, excluded data, or other manipulative techniques.

guideline: Create one or more impact business models

criteria.title: Theory of change
criteria.description: The organization has completed (and operationalized) a Theory of Change process with requisite documentation to identify the impact it hopes to create, how it will generate revenue, shared, or added value from these activities, how it will measure results based on desired outcomes; or in the case of launched projects, is generating revenue, actively tracking and measuring progress against any desired outcomes.

guideline: Follow a product management and maintenance strategy

criteria.title: Management and maintenance
criteria.description: The organization has documented policies outlining how it approaches product management and maintenance.

criteria.title: Planning strategy
criteria.description: The organization has maintenance / security plans in place for all the digital products and services it manages.

criteria.title: Resourcing products
criteria.description: The organization appropriately resources products over time via staffing and budgeting to support refactoring code, addressing technical debt, new product features, ongoing testing, and product or service maintenance plans to continue supporting its customers, visitors, and other stakeholders.

criteria.title: Resource measurement
criteria.description: The organization incorporates carbon and resource measurement into maintenance programs and can show measurable improvement over time.

criteria.title: Failure indicators
criteria.description: The organization has both identified and documented Key Failure Indicators (KFIs) and implements resolutions to prevent non-acceptable sustainability impacts from occurring.

guideline: Implement continuous improvement procedures

criteria.title: Continuous improvement
criteria.description: The organization has created policies and practices to enable continuous improvement and has resourced the organization appropriately to support these efforts over time.

criteria.title: Agile reviews
criteria.description: Agile sprints and update frequency have gone through a review process to ensure project teams have enough time to conduct user-research, identify technical debt, and produce quality output.

criteria.title: Iterative consideration
criteria.description: A track record of continuous improvement (iteration) usage to analyze your website or application while also addressing the by-products and potential consequences of ongoing experimentation, such as technical debt, product performance, emissions, and related issues is clearly visible. Analytics are limited to only necessary features to aid with decision-making, encouraging visitor feedback, and comparing performance against business goals and visitor needs.

criteria.title: Functionality decisions
criteria.description: The retention of existing features, the creation of new functionality, and the decommission or elimination of unused functionality, and unvisited pages through the product's life cycle have been justified and prioritized on a case by case basis.

criteria.title: Security updates
criteria.description: Corrective security and policy updates during the product or service lifecycle are provided, while such improvements are distinguished from more extensive evolutionary updates.

criteria.title: Skills and maintenance
criteria.description: Sustainable product and data strategies have been developed with appropriate training techniques. These should help your team (managers, colleagues, etc) build capacity and learn new skills to manage and maintain products and services over time.

guideline: Document future updates and evolutions

criteria.title: Feature changes
criteria.description: Adding, updating, or removing features are considered where appropriate to the user experience of the product or service.

guideline: Establish if a digital product or service is necessary

criteria.title: Sustainable Development Goals
criteria.description: The product or service identifies within a sustainability statement where it aligns with one of the U.N. (SDGs) and its appropriate targets.

criteria.title: Creation evaluation
criteria.description: The product or service has been determined as necessary based upon desirability, feasibility, and viability factors.

criteria.title: Avoid duplication
criteria.description: No existing digital product or service offers the same value. An analysis has been conducted if necessary to understand the market for this requirement.

criteria.title: Obstacle consideration
criteria.description: Any obstacles to using a product or service, such as accessibility, equality, technical, or territorial have been overcome.

guideline: Conduct a full life-cycle assessment

criteria.title: Life-cycle Assessment
criteria.description: A life-cycle Assessment (LCA) has been conducted to define the requirements of your product's function throughout its lifecycle.

guideline: Provide a supplier standards of practice

criteria.title: Vetting potential partners
criteria.description: The organization has created specific policies to vet potential partners in its supply chain based on PPP principles.

criteria.title: Collaborative measurement
criteria.description: The organization has partnered with suppliers to create, track, and measure collective impact on issues that impact their stakeholders.

criteria.title: Informative partner promotion
criteria.description: The organization has promoted its partnerships in a publicly available place, along with information on how the partnership creates a collective impact.

guideline: Share any economic benefits

criteria.title: Living wage
criteria.description: The organization is publicly committed to paying employees, contractors, and other stakeholders a living wage.

criteria.title: Incentivisation
criteria.description: The organization has policies and practices in place to incentivize stakeholders, such as workers and contractors, to meet its impact goals.

criteria.title: Employee benefits
criteria.description: The organization provides benefits to employees in accordance with its resources, including, where relevant, healthcare, retirement planning, flex time, profit sharing, and so on.

criteria.title: Legislation advocation
criteria.description: The organization advocates for responsible legislation that supports employment rights, transparency, and accountability related to sharing economic benefits.

guideline: Share decision-making power with appropriate stakeholders

criteria.title: Decision-making
criteria.description: The project team's goals are aligned with key business objectives, and project stakeholders (for example, project managers) have the power and autonomy to make key decisions on the organization's behalf.

guideline: Use Justice, Equity, Diversity, Inclusion (JEDI) practices

criteria.title: JEDI practices
criteria.description: The organization has documented its commitment to JEDI practices with clear policies on how it prioritizes marginalized or otherwise underserved communities, including Black, Indigenous, People of Color, LGBTQIA+, Women, Disabled, Veterans, Seniors, and so on.

criteria.title: Accessibility policy
criteria.description: The organization has an accessibility policy for digital products and services and can show this via a verified accessible website, application, product, or service.

criteria.title: JEDI training
criteria.description: The organization has JEDI-related training materials and schedules ongoing workshops related to how this topic manifests itself in digital products and services (algorithmic bias, digital divide, gig economy work, mis / disinformation, etc).

criteria.title: JEDI improvements
criteria.description: The organization can show measurable JEDI improvement over time in its hiring, leadership, and operations.

criteria.title: JEDI legislation
criteria.description: The organization advocates for responsible legislation relating to JEDI practices, especially as related to digital products and services.

guideline: Promote responsible data practices

criteria.title: Privacy policy
criteria.description: The organization maintains a publicly accessible Privacy Policy, Terms and Conditions, or any other documents required by local law, that adhere to the most restrictive data protection regulations, especially when providing services outside the organization's country. These documents are available in accessible formats and use clear, user-friendly language to ensure comprehension by all visitors, avoiding jargon, technical language, and legalese. The organization also supports emerging legislation and implements best practices related to data privacy, sustainability, and responsible data management.

criteria.title: Data ownership
criteria.description: The organization can show measurable progress over time in respecting data privacy and ownership. This will include how the organization handles data disposal and a visitor's "right to be forgotten", along with ownership rights and providing the ability to download / export data they have contributed into a non-proprietary format.

guideline: Implement appropriate data management procedures

criteria.title: Outdated content
criteria.description: Outdated or otherwise expired product content and data are archived and deleted via automated expiration dates and scheduled product audits. An archiving schedule with a lighter version of the old searchable content is made available.

criteria.title: Data controllers
criteria.description: Users can control, manage, and delete their data, subscriptions, and accounts.

guideline: Promote and implement responsible emerging technology practices

criteria.title: Emerging technologies
criteria.description: The organization has public-facing policies in place for emerging technologies, and all such technologies are ethically sourced, screened, validated, and implemented in a non-discriminatory, responsible manner.

criteria.title: Disruptive technology
criteria.description: The organization shows how it up-skills workers as new technologies and practices potentially disrupt its business model.

criteria.title: Technology legislation
criteria.description: The organization supports and complies with responsible legislation related to automation and emerging technologies (such as the EU AI Act).

criteria.title: Environmental responsibilities
criteria.description: Organizations must consider, audit, and account for any environmental considerations that may derive from the use of emerging technologies they wish to either promote or implement within a chosen setting. Also note that this should include third-party choices, the "expense" (in terms of waste or emissions) of the utilization of the technology to create a desired result and consequential issues to the environment that may arise from its deployment.

criteria.title: Automated tooling
criteria.description: Automated tooling, scrapers, spiders, bots, Artificial Intelligence, and other forms of machine-assisted data gathering must abide by requests to opt out at the host, server, or website level. Providers must declare themselves as non-human when requesting within the user-agent / HTTP header. Providers must also publish impact reports relating to their gathering activities.

criteria.title: Quantum resilience
criteria.description: Don't roll out post-quantum encryption for high-traffic services that don't need resilience against harvest now, decrypt later.

guideline: Include responsible financial policies

criteria.title: Fuel divestment
criteria.description: The organization has divested from fossil fuels and moved its banking, sponsorship, and other affiliations to more responsible partners.

criteria.title: Responsible finance
criteria.description: The organization engages in flexible financing and responsible budgeting for its digital products and services to accommodate long-term care and maintenance.

guideline: Include organizational philanthropy policies

criteria.title: Philanthropy policy
criteria.description: The organization has a clear corporate giving policy and creates philanthropic partnerships with strategically aligned organizations.

criteria.title: Voluntary work
criteria.description: The organization engages in free or volunteer projects, which help its team learn new tools and tactics, while also helping charities and non-profit organizations build capacity.

guideline: Plan for a digital product or service's care and end-of-life

criteria.title: End-of-life care
criteria.description: Clear, documented end-of-life guidelines exist that include data disposal, archiving, file deletion, etc guidance.

guideline: Include e-waste, right-to-repair, and recycling policies

criteria.title: E-Waste policy
criteria.description: The organization has specific policies in place to recycle e-waste and repair owned technology products whenever possible.

criteria.title: Recycling and repairing
criteria.description: The organization has formed relationships with local partners for e-waste recycling and repair.

criteria.title: Refurbishment strategy
criteria.description: The organization buys refurbished equipment whenever possible.

criteria.title: Right-to-repair
criteria.description: The organization allows consumers to repair (to the best of their ability) the consumables they purchase, offering (if possible at cost) replacement components and provides clear instructions to resolve faults that occur.

guideline: Define performance and environmental budgets

criteria.title: Environmental budget
criteria.description: The product team has defined, baselined, and documented clear sustainability and environmental budget criteria that cover the page, user-journey, and digital service levels and metrics (such as a CO2.js score) that are approved by relevant product stakeholders.

criteria.title: Performance budget
criteria.description: Tools such as a performance budget exist to determine the maximum size (goals) your app or website can weigh to reduce the data transfer and HTTP request impact (using metrics like Google Lighthouse).

criteria.title: Human budget
criteria.description: KPIs are defined around engineering hours, development time, or sprints keeping the health and wellbeing of your workers paramount. Consideration has been taken around optimizing your workflow sustainably to allow all tasks to be performed with care.

criteria.title: Measurable improvements
criteria.description: The product team can measurably show how much the budgeting process improved performance and reduced emissions.

criteria.title: Capacity and maintenance
criteria.description: The product team invests in resources to build capacity and maintain the budgets over time.

guideline: Use open source where possible

criteria.title: Open source policy
criteria.description: The organization has a clear open source policy in place that outlines how it uses open source tools and the practices it supports surrounding open source development.

criteria.title: Collaboration
criteria.description: The organization has a track record of collaboration and community-building around open source principles.

criteria.title: Contribution
criteria.description: The organization regularly contributes to open source community-based projects.

guideline: Create a business continuity and disaster recovery plan

criteria.title: Plan of action
criteria.description: The organization has created a plan of action that is regularly reviewed and occasionally tested to determine readiness in case of an incident and has procedures to quickly recover from such issues.

criteria.title: Audience awareness
criteria.description: The organization regularly maintains transparent communication with its audience regarding issues that may affect service delivery or user data.
